subject: Move 'upload_image' policy check to the controller

values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I'm sorry that I didn't look at this sooner.  Abhishek, thanks for working with Bhagyashri on this.  I think the code is good, but I have a concern.

This patch will give us two policies to work with:

(1) upload_image - governs whether you can successfully make the PUT .../file call

(2) import_image - governs whether you can successfully make the POST .../import call

(I like moving enforcement to the controller, by the way, it's good to have things fail fast.)

The problem is that policy (2) will allow a user to make the PUT .../stage call to stage some data, but then that user won't be able to do anything with it.  I think it would be better to have a stage_image policy to govern whether a user can put data into the stage.  With no staged data, a user won't be able to make the POST .../import call.  (I should have been more explicit about this when we discussed it.)

Actually, that's not true, as the copy-from and swift-local methods won't have staged data.  So if we want to allow operators to restrict import to particular users--or more likely, to prevent some users from importing images, we will in fact need your import_image policy.

So I think what we need here is also to introduce a 'stage_image' policy.  Since it would be an addition, it doesn't necessarily need to hold up this patch.  I'd be interested in what the other cores think about (a) the stage_image policy, and (b) whether stage_image and import_image need to go in together, or whether this can merge for Q-2 with stage_image as a follow-on.

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Response to Abhishek's point inline.

Patch Set 3:

> I'm sorry that I didn't look at this sooner.  Abhishek, thanks for
 > working with Bhagyashri on this.  I think the code is good, but I
 > have a concern.
 > 
 > This patch will give us two policies to work with:
 > 
 > (1) upload_image - governs whether you can successfully make the
 > PUT .../file call
 > 
 > (2) import_image - governs whether you can successfully make the
 > POST .../import call
 > 
 > (I like moving enforcement to the controller, by the way, it's good
 > to have things fail fast.)
 > 
 > The problem is that policy (2) will allow a user to make the PUT
 > .../stage call to stage some data, but then that user won't be able
 > to do anything with it.  I think it would be better to have a
 > stage_image policy to govern whether a user can put data into the
 > stage.  With no staged data, a user won't be able to make the POST
 > .../import call.  (I should have been more explicit about this when
 > we discussed it.)
 > 
 > Actually, that's not true, as the copy-from and swift-local methods
 > won't have staged data.  So if we want to allow operators to
 > restrict import to particular users--or more likely, to prevent
 > some users from importing images, we will in fact need your
 > import_image policy.
 > 
 > So I think what we need here is also to introduce a 'stage_image'
 > policy.  Since it would be an addition, it doesn't necessarily need
 > to hold up this patch.  I'd be interested in what the other cores
 > think about (a) the stage_image policy, and (b) whether stage_image
 > and import_image need to go in together, or whether this can merge
 > for Q-2 with stage_image as a follow-on.

Hi Brian,

It completely make sense to have image_stage policy as user will be able to put the data but will not be able to import the same. As these two calls are interrelated can we have a single policy for the same like image_stage_import? which will be enforced for both the calls?

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> I'm sorry that I didn't look at this sooner.  Abhishek, thanks for
 > working with Bhagyashri on this.  I think the code is good, but I
 > have a concern.
 > 
 > This patch will give us two policies to work with:
 > 
 > (1) upload_image - governs whether you can successfully make the
 > PUT .../file call
 > 
 > (2) import_image - governs whether you can successfully make the
 > POST .../import call
 > 
 > (I like moving enforcement to the controller, by the way, it's good
 > to have things fail fast.)
 > 
 > The problem is that policy (2) will allow a user to make the PUT
 > .../stage call to stage some data, but then that user won't be able
 > to do anything with it.  I think it would be better to have a
 > stage_image policy to govern whether a user can put data into the
 > stage.  With no staged data, a user won't be able to make the POST
 > .../import call.  (I should have been more explicit about this when
 > we discussed it.)
 > 
 > Actually, that's not true, as the copy-from and swift-local methods
 > won't have staged data.  So if we want to allow operators to
 > restrict import to particular users--or more likely, to prevent
 > some users from importing images, we will in fact need your
 > import_image policy.
 > 
 > So I think what we need here is also to introduce a 'stage_image'
 > policy.  Since it would be an addition, it doesn't necessarily need
 > to hold up this patch.  I'd be interested in what the other cores
 > think about (a) the stage_image policy, and (b) whether stage_image
 > and import_image need to go in together, or whether this can merge
 > for Q-2 with stage_image as a follow-on.

Hi Brain, Thanks for review.

I am agree to the point and completely make sense that it would be better to have a stage_image policy separately
to govern whether a user can put data at stage call and also operator will have better control.
IMO we need to introduce new policy for stage API call. So I will submit follow-on patch as early as possible.

Patch Set 3:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Comment inline.

I agree here so throwing this out:

what if we have a "StageImage" (some-bikeshed-name) object that is not really an image but a stage image though inherited from Image and ImageRepo classes. This might 'also' help govern the indefinite number of blank images that can be created if we do plan to do so.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

just -1 to indicate that I do not prefer to go a hacky route for policy manipulations as policies are hard to deal with as is. though if priority of GTD is more precedent, I am willing to consider otherwise.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

We definitely need more discussion on this, am rescheduling the bug this is associated with to Q-3.  But that doesn't mean we need to wait to discuss it.  Let's settle this issue as soon as possible.
Uploaded patch set 5.

Patch Set 5:

I guess now you should change commit message as per discussion yesterday happened on openstack-glance irc channel. For example glance is planning to remove policy layer by moving policy checks to controller layer.
